Empirical literature suggests debt limit for developing countries is broadly between 35 and 55 percent of GDP; I took the midpoint of the range, using the year from Tran (2018) study referenced in the text.
Panel threshold analysis by Tran (2018) reveals debt thresholds of 40– 55 percent; I took the midpoint of the range, using the year from Tran (2018) study referenced in the text.
Panel threshold analysis by Tran (2018) reveals debt thresholds of 35 percent, using the year from Tran (2018) study referenced in the text.

After public debt exceeds a certain threshold level (55 percent of GDP), it is negatively correlated with economic activity, using the year from Baharumshah et al. (2017) study referenced in the text.
After public debt exceeds a certain threshold level (55 percent of GDP), it is negatively correlated with economic activity, using the year from Greenidge et al. (2012) study referenced in the text.
Baseline estimation result. Implies the debt-to-GDP ratio at which the primary balance is maximized, based on fiscal reaction function estimation.
Robustness check (with terms of trade). Implies the debt-to-GDP ratio at which the primary balance is maximized, based on fiscal reaction function estimation.
Baseline estimation result. Primary Balance corresponding to the debt-to-GDP ratio that maximizes primary balance.
Robustness check (with terms of trade). Primary Balance corresponding to the debt-to-GDP ratio that maximizes primary balance.
Debt dynamics examined starting from the government’s cash-flow constraint. 0 indicates a starting point for analysis.
Estimated nonlinear relationship with debt level. 0 indicates a starting point for analysis. The relationship is found to be weakly related based on empirical observation.
Implied target based on nominal GDP growth of 5% and debt target of 30%

Calculated as a 0.4 percent marginal fiscal stimulus suggested by the disaster-resilient fiscal rule.
Non-resource, non-recurrent budget balance needs to be smaller than -0.4 percent of GDP to accommodate the shock.
Roughly estimated amount for public investment or emergency relief based on the non-resource, non-recurrent budget balance deviation.
The impact of the earthquake is assumed to be around 3% of GDP.
